msIdentifier.repository: Pembroke College Library: on long-term deposit at Cambridge University Library

summary.seg: This Gospel lectionary manuscript was probably copied in the 12th century, although it has been suggested that it is a product of the 13th century or later, produced in deliberate imitation of the style of an earlier period. The inclusion of a feast particular to the liturgical calendar of Constantinople (f. 39v) may indicate that it was produced in the Byzantine capital, though it could merely reflect the reproduction of a feature of the exemplar from which it was copied. Its elegant and somewhat unconventional minuscule script is unusually large, a feature probably related to its similarly unusual content, which is much more limited than that of a conventional lectionary and differently arranged.

In the usual arrangement of a lectionary, the early part of the book contains the synaxarion, the readings of the movable calendar beginning from Easter, followed by the menologion, containing the lections of the fixed calendar beginning from 1 September, sometimes followed by miscellaneous readings. While the selection of lections in the menologion varies greatly between different manuscripts, the synaxarion normally falls into one of two standard varieties. The "weekday" type, typically for monastic use, includes lections for the whole week, except in Lent, when the New Testament was read only on Saturdays and Sundays, while the "Saturday-Sunday" type generally used in other churches contains only the lections for those two days, except in Holy Week and the period between Easter and Pentecost, when weekday lections are also included. In this manuscript, however, not only is the range of feasts included in the menologion very small, but only a handful of the most important days in the movable calendar appear. The order is also unconventional, since the readings of the synaxarion for Lent which are included appear after the menologion rather than preceding it. Given the focus on major festivals, it is likely that at least some of the lections of Holy Week would have followed, but much of the later part of the manuscript is missing, including its end.

The size of the script implies a superfluity of funds, since it constitutes an inefficient use of expensive parchment. Other manuscripts of this rare type include exceptionally opulent examples such as Florence, Biblioteca Medicea Laurentiana, MS Med. Palat. 244, whose text is gilded throughout. A degree of conspicuous consumption is also suggested by the very existence of such a book, whose content was completely inadequate for the day-to-day needs of a church, and implies that an institution already possessing a lectionary sufficient for its needs acquired an additional one for special occasions. However, the availability of funds may not have remained consistent throughout the project. The use of gold for headings, ubiquitous in the early folios, subsequently becomes more restricted and then disappears entirely, though reappearing towards the end. Gold does, however, remain in use throughout for the ornamented initial letters of each lection and other decoration.

The opening folios are, most unusually, written entirely in red ink, usually reserved for headings, before abruptly switching to the more usual brown, in the transition from recto to verso of the same folio (f. 3r-3v). The accompanying ekphonetic musical notation, which guided the chanting of the text and was normally written in red, appears instead in blue on the pages written in red, before reverting to its more normal colour at the same time as the text. Since text for gilding was usually written in red ink before being covered with gold, this could imply that this lectionary was at first intended as a truly deluxe production like the Laurentiana manuscript, but that this ambition was curtailed at an early stage, before the further reductions in the use of gold already mentioned. However, the use of blue ekphonetic notation suggests that the initial intention was for the main text to remain red, calling for the use of a different colour to keep the notation clearly distinct. The early abandonment of the initial scheme may nonetheless reflect a reduction in resources, but from a somewhat more modest starting point.

Three of the lections are accompanied by later notes in Arabic to identify them. This indicates that the manuscript spent part of its history in use by an Arabic-speaking Christian community in the Middle East, whose members retained Greek as their liturgical language but did not understand it well, and would thereore find such annotations helpful in finding the right text. One of these annotations, however, in fact identifies the lection incorrectly. Its provenance remains somewhat mysterious, since it was brought to Britain in the early 20th century by a man who then died without revealing where he had acquired it. Ellis Minns, the Librarian of Pembroke College who subsequently purchased it, reported that the sand and variety of dead insects which he found between the leaves led him to suppose that it had spent time in a desert monastery.

By this time, as well as losing many of its folios and suffering severely from water damage, the manuscript had lost its last binding, and it remains unbound apart from its damaged endbands and small remnants of its sewing. It is presently protected by a loose leather wrapper which was clearly once the covering material of a book, and whose appearance would be consistent with the kind of provenance suggested by Minns. However, this cover was evidently not that of the manuscript's own former binding, since its structure implies that the book for which it was made had a different sewing arrangement.

msItem.title: Gospel lectionary (selective)
msItem.note: Defective at the beginning and end, with lacunas: the text begins during the lection for the Monday after Easter (Jn 1:7) and ends during the lection for the Saturday of Lazarus (Jn 11:7)
msItem.incipit: f. 1r ρα Θεοῦ· ὄνομα αὐτῶ, Ἰωάννης οὗτος ἦλθεν εἰς μαρτυρίαν
msItem.explicit: f. 88v λέγει τοῖς μαθηταῖς ἄγωμεν εἰς τὴν Ἰουδαίαν πάλιν

msItem.title: Synaxarion: Lections for the week after Easter (Diakainesimou)
Synaxarion: Lection for Antipascha (1st Sunday after Easter)
Synaxarion: Lection for Mesopentekoste (4th Wednesday after Easter)
Synaxarion: Lection for Ascension Day (6th Thursday after Easter)
Synaxarion: Lection for All Saints (1st Sunday after Pentecost
Menologion: Lections for December
msItem.note: Defective at the end; contains minor lacunas due to damage to the gutter

msItem.title: Menologion: Lections for January
msItem.note: Defective at the beginning and end; contains a lacuna due to the loss of folios

msItem.title: Synaxarion: Lections for the 1st Saturday and Sunday of Lent
Synaxarion: Lection for the Saturday of Lazarus
msItem.note: Defective at the beginning and end

support.material: Parchment (FHHF), of medium thickness and good quality.

supportDesc.foliation: The manuscript is foliated with the numbers [i] + 1-83, [83a], 84-87, [87a], 88 in pencil, in Arabic numerals, recto, upper right.

collation.p: The manuscript consists of 13 quires, of which one is a quinion and the rest are quaternia. One original quire has been lost after Quire 8, and another six after the present Quire 11

list.item: Quire 18-1+1 ff. [i]-8 The first folio has been lost, with loss of text, and a modern blank paper leaf attached to the stub in its place.
Quire 710-1 ff. 48-56 The original penultimate folio has been cancelled, without loss of text, and another bifolio added during the original process of production.
Quire 118-6 ff. 81-82 The first, third-six and eighth folios have been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 128-2+2 ff. 83-88 The second and seventh folios have been lost, with loss of text, and a modern blank paper bifolio inserted in their place.

collation.signatures: There are original quire signatures in Greek numerals, in red ink, on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower right. They survive on Quires 2-10 and 12 (βʹ-ηʹ, ιʹ-ιαʹ, ιθʹ).

There are modern leaf signatures, in Greek numerals for quires and Roman numerals for folios, in pencil, on each folio, recto, lower right. The leaf number has later been repeated in Arabic numerals in pencil next to some of these signatures.

supportDesc.condition: There have been extensive losses in the gutter to many folios, sometimes causing loss of text, which have been repaired with paper patches, creating some hinging on some folios and restricting the opening of others. There is a tear in the gutter to f. 38 and tears to the other edges of various folios, some of which have also been repaired with paper patches. Numerous worm-holes and other small holes are present in the outer folios (ff. 1-6, 83-88). There is significant creasing, sometimes obscuring text, and the edges of the folios are brittle, with a worn area on the tail-edge. There is extensive and serious water damage, especially in the gutter, which has led to some blurring of the text, and there is abrasion of the ink in places.

layoutDesc.layout:
A single column of 12 lines.
151 135
Pricking does not survive. Ruled in hardpoint, system Leroy 1, type 34C2. Text hangs from the lines.

handNote.p: The main text was copied in an unusually large mixed minuscule script, slanting slightly to the right, with significant variation in letter size. The text of ff. 1r-3r was written in red ink, the remainder of the manuscript in brown ink.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear only at the end of lines. Breathings are usually round but sometimes angular. Mute iota is usually absent but occasionally present. It appears in a number of transitional forms, in adscript position but reduced in size to varying degrees (e.g. f. 50v, col. a, line 10, f. 65r, col. a, line 11) or below the right-hand end of the letter (e.g. f. 26r, col. a, line 10). Use of the double dot is functional only, and there is accentuation of all lengths of nomina sacra. Nomina sacra are occasionally uncontracted (e.g. f. 64v, col. b, line 12). Circumflexes are not expanded, even when appearing above breathings. Accents are sometimes joined to abbreviations. The double grave accent and marginal quotation marks are in use.

Distinctive letter forms include minuscule delta with a very short ascender (e.g. f. 56v, col. b, lines 6, 11), majuscule lambda with the lower right-hand stroke curved inwards, majuscule lambda with the upper stroke elongated and coiled inwards (e.g. f. 72v, col. a, line 8), large lunate sigma wrapped around the following letter and extending further below than above, and large tau with the horizontal curved.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas, question mark and full stop.

Headings for lections on ff. 3r-18r were written in epigraphic display majuscule in red ink and gilded, and thereafter in Alexandrine majuscule script with some minuscule forms, written in red ink and gilded on ff. 20v-34r in red ink only on ff. 37r-83v, but with the reappearance of gilding on f. 85v, the last surviving folio with headings. Headings indicating the Gospel are written in the latter script, in red ink only on ff. 5r-20v, 26v and 37r-85v and with gilding on ff. 3r, 23v, 30v and 34r.

physDesc.musicNotation: The text is supplied throughout with ekphonetic notation, in blue ink on ff. 1r-3r and red ink through the remainder of the manuscript.

decoDesc.decoNote: The beginning of the menologion (f. 39v and of the lections of Lent (f. 83v) are preceded by headpieces in a plait or interlace pattern, drawn in red ink and gilded.
Lections on ff. 63r, 65r, 77v are preceded by simpler vignettes, drawn in red ink and gilded.
Each lection begins with an ornamented major initial, either in gold or outlined in gold and infilled with red, blue, green, yellow and white paint.
Gilded headings are present on ff. 3r-34r and 85v.

additions.p: As part of the original process of production, the text is supplied with headings identifying lections, which sometimes appear in the margin and sometimes in the line of text, and headings identifying the Gospel, always in the line of text.

There are notes in Arabic identifying lections on ff. 30v (6th Sunday after Easter), 34r (Pentecost) and 37r (1st Sunday after Pentecost). The note on f. 30v is incorrect, as it appears next to the lection for Ascension Day, and there is no lection for the sixth Sunday after Easter in this manuscript (Minns, pp. 217-218).
A note on the modern replacement folio f. [i] recto records the purchase and posited date of the manuscript: 310 Evangelistarium Graece. saeculum XI-XII emptum A.D. MCMXXIIII. Pret. XV. LI.

binding.p: The manuscript has lost its boards and most of its sewing, of which only small fragments remain, and for which there were four sewing-stations. Both endbands survive in part, sewn with bright red thread around a round core and through a blue textile. Traces of paint indicate that the edges were once painted red. The text block is wrapped in a loose leather cover with turn-ins, decorated on both faces with a simple border and diagonal lines using fillets. There are ridges on the spine for three stations of a supported sewing as well as for the endbands, the position of which does not correspond to that of the sewing-stations or endbands of the text block. There is no indication of grooves at the edges of the boards to which the cover was attached.
binding.condition: The endbands are fragile. Parts of the leather cover have been lost and there are tears to what remains, which contains numerous small holes due to pest damage. The left outer joint is partially split.

physDesc.accMat: The manuscript is housed along with detailed handwritten notes on the content, comparisons with other manuscripts and views on date and origin by Ellis Minns, further notes on the content by another hand, and exhibition labels.

history.origin: The manuscript was probably copied in the 12th century, as suggested by Easterling (p. 188). It has been variously dated in the past, Minns favouring a date in the 11th or 12th century, while reporting that Robert Devreesse argued that it was an archaising product of the 13th century or later, imitating the style of the 11th century, owing to features such as the downward extension of some letters (Minns, pp. 215-217). However, the occasional presence of angular breathings in a text usually employing round ones seems more consistent with a 12th-century date than with either the faithful imitation of 11th-century practice or the inadvertant retention of 13th-century or later norms, although their presence in 13th-century manuscripts is not unknown. The considerable variation in the size of letters and the range of transitional forms of mute iota present also seem to rule out either a genuine 11th-century production or an effective imitation of one. Devreesse, Giovanni Mercati and a Dr Gianelli, in correspondence reported by Minns, suggested that it was produced in the Aegean islands, while Minns argued for production in Constantinople (Minns, pp. 215-217), on the basis of its similarity to the lavish Florence, Biblioteca Medicea Laurentiana, MS Med. Palat. 244 and the distinctive reference to the Chalkoprateia in the lection heading for 1 September (f. 39v). The feast this alludes to was particular to Constantinople, though it does not necessarily indicate production in the capital, since it could have been simply reproduced from the manuscript's exemplar.
history.provenance: Bought by Ellis H. Minns (1874-1953), Fellow and Librarian of Pembroke in 1924 from the bookseller F.M. Barnard (no. 191 in Barnard's Catalogue for 1924). Minns reports that Barnard had acquired it from another firm, following the death of an unnamed man who brought it to Britain from an unknown source. The presence of Arabic notes suggests that it had spent time in Egypt or the Levant, as noted by Minns, who also remarks that the sand and dead insects between the leaves suggest that it had previously been housed in a desert location (Minns, pp. 217-218).
history.acquisition: Given to Pembroke College by Minns in 1924.

availability.p: Researchers should note that Pembroke College's western European medieval manuscripts are housed at Cambridge University Library (CUL). Scholars who wish to consult Pembroke College manuscripts should contact the Manuscripts Reading Room at CUL to arrange their visit; all CUL admissions procedures will apply. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library. For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.
